//TEST DESCRIPTIONS
This is the first test done by a doctor or nurse. A series of tests will be done to check the body for abnormalities. The doctor or nurse will ask about medications taken and try to figure out why you are not feeling well.
This is a blood test is used to assess your overall health. It\'s performed during an exam by a doctor or nurse to check for infection, low blood values, and other diseases.
This blood test measures the amount of Valproic Acid in the blood stream. Valproic acid is an anticonvulsant medication used for patients who are prone to seizures.
Blood is drawn from two different veins to check an infection in the blood. The blood is then sent to the laboratory for testing. The negative or positive results will not be available the same day, as it takes time for the bacteria in the blood to grow.
An OBGYN is a doctor that helps young and older women. They treat diseases in a woman\'s reproductive system and also deliver babies.
This procedure is done by a doctor or nurse practitioner. They perform a exam through the vagina to check for bleeding, infection, or reasons a woman has pain.
This blood test is used to assess overall health. It tests the kidneys, the blood sugar and important electrolytes in the body.
This medicine kills bacteria in the body. Doctors give this medicine to patients who have infections like pneumonia or urine infections.
OBGYN is short for doctors who are specialists in obstetrics and gynecology. These doctors treat and care for women\'s reproductive systems, pregnancies and childbirth.
This blood test provides information on how fast a patient\'s blood clots. If a patient is taking a blood thinner, the doctor will check this blood test to make sure the medicine is the right dosage.
Sutures are also known as stitches. These are used to repair cuts which will not heal unless the skin is pulled together for an extended time period.
This blood test is done to see if a patient\'s heart is working correctly. It is usually tested when a patient has gained weight, has swollen legs, a hard time breathing or has congestive heart failure.
A visual acuity test is done to see how well a patient can see. It is always done when a patient has an eye injury or is having trouble seeing. The patient will stand 20 feet from a piece of paper (Snellen Chart) with letters on it. The patient reads the smallest letters they can to get a visual acuity score.
This blood test measures how much Acetaminophen is in the blood. This drug is also known as Tylenol. It is commonly used for pain relief, but is dangerous if a patient takes too much.
This blood test measures how much aspirin is in the blood. Aspirin has many benefits for pain relief and heart conditions but is also dangerous if a patient takes too much.
A rapid strep test tests for a bacteria in the back of the throat. This bacteria commonly causes a sore throat, fever and overall body aches.
Eye drops are small drops of liquid medicine that are put into the eye for multiple different reasons including pain control or to treat infections or damage to the eye.
This blood test is used to assess overall health. It performs over 10 tests that check kidneys, blood sugar, electrolytes and the liver.
This blood test checks the body for high levels of lipase. High amounts of lipase may indicate that a patient has pancreatitis or swelling of the pancreas. Most often patients will also have pain in their abdomen, have a fever and feel nauseated.
This blood test checks for diseases within the body. Doctors use this test to check for inflammation, swelling, pain or arthritis. It doesn\'t tell the doctor exactly what disease is there, but does confirm there is something abnormal in the body.
This blood test is done when the doctor thinks a patient may have a blood clot in their body. These clots most commonly form in the legs, arms or in the lungs. Clots can cause the patient\'s arms or legs to be painful or chest pain and trouble breathing if the clot is in the lung.
This blood test checks for any signals that there was damage done to a patient\'s heart. This damage may have been from a heart attack or another heart condition. It\'s common to draw a troponin blood test when a patient has chest pain or trouble breathing properly.
The ER doctor speaks with admitting doctors. Admitting doctors will do more testing and observe patients who are staying in the hospital.
A computer screen in the room monitors a patient\'s heart and lungs. It records how fast their heart beats, how fast they breathes, their oxygen level and their blood pressure.
This test is used to check the blood sugar level in the blood. The doctor or nurse pricks the patient\'s finger and tests a small drop of blood.
This blood test checks for an infection in the patient\'s abdomen. It may be done if a patient is getting stomach aches, drinks a lot of alcohol, or is having trouble eating and drinking.
These are doctors who specialize in caring for a patient\'s digestive tract. This includes the esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and biliary system (liver, pancreas, gallbladder, ad bile ducts).
This test is a collection of stool. Diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, or blood in the stool would be common reasons for this test to be performed.
This blood test checks the overall health of the liver. The liver is a large organ that turns food into energy. Dark urine, abdominal pain, being tired, or yellow skin are all reasons this test may be done.
This blood test is used to determine if a woman is pregnant by testing the level of HCG hormone in the blood. HCG levels go up in the first 3 months of pregnancy. The test may also be done if a woman has vaginal bleeding or cramping.
This blood test checks for problems with your thyroid. A thyroid is a glad in your throat. If there are problems with your thyroid, you may be gaining or losing weight, have mood swings, or be more tired than normal. Under-active thyroid and over-active thyroid each have different symptoms.
This blood test measures the level of uric acid in your bloodstream. Uric acid increases when your kidneys can not properly rid it from your body through urinating. Most commonly excessive uric acid is seen when patients have increasing pain in their joints or kidney stones. In addition, symptoms of gout may be present, which includes joint swelling and redness.
This blood test is done if the doctor thinks a patient has lost blood or is going to have surgery. This test identifies what blood type the patient is. If the patient does need a blood transfusion, the doctor will then know what type of blood to give the patient.
Blood types: O positive, O negative, A positive, A negative, B positive, B negative, AB positive, AB negative
This is a test that looks for infections or blood in the urine. It is usually done when a patient has a hard time urinating, it burns to urinate, or during a physical.
This is a blood test that is taken from either the vein or the artery usually in the arm or wrist. It is used to evaluate how well a patient’s lungs are functioning. Having excessive acid (acidosis) or base (alkalosis) can be extremely dangerous to a patient’s health.
These tests are commonly done when a person has difficulty breathing, has increasing fatigue, is disoriented, or has had excessive smoke inhalation.
12 stickers are put onto the arms, legs and chest. The stickers are connected to a computer that draws a picture of electricity in the heart. The doctor looks at the picture to determine if there is anything abnormal with the body or with the heart. This test is often done in the emergency department or the doctors office.
During IV Placement, a small needle is put into the patients arm. It is uncomfortable at first, but will be taken out immediately. A small plastic catheter will remain in the arm to test the patient\'s blood or give them medicine.
This therapy is often referred to as an “IV drip”. During this process, liquid is infused into the vein through an IV catheter. This therapy can be used to correct electrolyte imbalances, rehydrate, give medications, or transfuse blood.
IV fluid goes into the IV catheter in the patient\'s vein. IV fluid is given to help patients who are dehydrated or have been vomiting. It contains many nutrients that are important to the body.
This test is used to diagnose the flu (influenza). A doctor or nurse will puts a Q-tip shaped swab into the back of the nose to check for the influenza. The test does not hurt, but is uncomfortable and may tickle the back of the nose or make the patient cough.
This test determines how well the patient is breathing in the air around them. To perform this test, a small needle put into the patient\'s arm and a blood sample is drawn from the artery or vein.
This test is performed to evaluate the sugar level in a the blood. After pricking the finger, a small drop of blood is tested using an blood glucose level machine. This test may be performed to asses causes of blurred vision, increased urination, weight loss, increased thirst, confusion, or other diabetes. The test results are usually available in less than 15 seconds.
During this procedure, a tube is inserted into the bladder through the penis or vagina. This tube helps patients urinate if they are very sick or are not able to urinate. After the tube is in place, it is normal for patients to feel a little discomfort. Urine automatically drains through this tube into a bag hooked to the side of the bed.
Swab samples are taken during a vaginal exam. These are called cultures. They are sent to the laboratory to be tested for bacteria that cause infection, pain, or bleeding. Most commonly, the pain is found in a woman\'s vagina or abdomen.
Breathing treatments are given through a device that turns medicine into a mist. Patients put the device in their mouth and breathe the medicine into their lungs. This medicine will help to open airways in the lungs making it easier to breathe. It is often used in patients with asthma or COPD (cardio obstructive pulmonary disease).
After taking a deep breath, a patient blows into the end of the peak flow meter device as hard as they can. This number is used to tell the doctor how well the patient\'s lungs are working.
If any dirt or chemicals get into a patient\'s eyes, the eyes needs to be cleaned. Patients can clean their eyes using the eye wash station in the hospital or use a special tool called a Morgan Lens. It is important to try to wash out the dirt or chemicals as soon as possible. This helps to stop any serious long term damage to the eye.
There are many different types of pain medication. Each medication is given for different types and location of pain. The different types of pain medication are: Narcotics, Non-Narcotics, Non Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs), and creams that go on the skin.
Nausea medications are given to patients who have been throwing up or feel sick to their stomach. They are commonly used in the emergency department or after surgery. They can be given in pill form or through an IV catheter.
Extra blood is given to patients who have had sudden blood loss. This may have been from an accident or some type of unknown bleeding. The blood will be given through the IV in the patient\'s arm or another catheter such as a PICC line or a port. A doctor will speak with the patient before receiving any blood and answer any questions at that time.
Tetanus is a potentially fatal disease in the central nervous system. The bacteria can enter into the body through a cut in the skin. It can take anywhere from 3-21 days to have symptoms of tetanus which include jaw stiffness (lockjaw), fast heart rate, sweating, stiffness in facial muscles, difficult swallowing and others. Children and adults are given tetanus vaccines through intramuscular shots as well as booster shots. Consult with your physician to get the most up to date information on your tetanus vaccination status.
An X-ray is a picture taken of certain parts of a patient\'s body. These pictures help the doctor see broken bones, infections, or other problems in the body. These are usually done in the emergency department or doctors office.
A CT Scan takes detailed pictures of the body. It looks at organs, muscles, fat and bones. It is more detailed than an X-Ray and is often used for patients with headaches, abdominal pain or chest pain.
This painless test is used to show the doctor pictures of a patient\'s organs or blood flow in the body. It can take detailed pictures of the heart beating, the kidneys, breasts, or look for blood clots in the legs, arms, veins or arteries. It may also be used to show pictures of a baby during pregnancy.
An MRI machine takes a picture of the body using magnets and radio waves. It is one of the most detailed test that can be done to see every detail of organs, bones, fat or tissue. During this test, patients lay flat on their back on a table. The table slides in and out of a donut shaped machine. The machine does make a lot of noise, but it is not painful. The test usually takes between 30 minutes and 1 hour.
This painless procedure is similar to an ultrasound and checks how well the heart is working. Jelly is put onto the chest and a probe is put against the skin to take pictures of the heart as it beats. This can be used to help diagnose heart conditions or defects.
This test is done while walking on a treadmill or riding on a stationary bike. A doctor or nurse will monitor the patient\'s heart speed, breathing speed and blood pressure during the test. This test is done to check for abnormal heart beats and to make sure the heart is getting enough blood and oxygen.
Patients are given extra oxygen through a mask (non-rebreather) or tubes in their nose (nasal cannula) to help with breathing. This extra oxygen will help to raise the oxygen level in the blood, making patients to feel better.
This blood test indicates inflammation inside the body. If there is inflammation inside the body, the level of this test will rise.
This blood test is used to test patients who may be confused or extremely sick. It is commonly elevated in patients with liver problems.
This blood test is done on patients that a doctor thinks may be very sick. It tests for large infections in the body and may also be used after an injury or to see if a patient\'s is getting better.
Swallow Screen is an evaluation that assesses if it is safe to allow a patient to swallow food, water, or medication. If a patient has difficulty completing the swallow screen, generally the patient will not be allowed to eat or drink (NPO). These are done mainly on patients who exhibit signs or symptoms of having had or recently had a stroke.
These doctors treat diseases or injuries in the brain or spinal cord. They do this by doing surgery or using medication.
These are doctors who treat problems with the brain. They also specialize in treating the nervous system, muscles and spinal cord.
These are doctors who specialize in caring for male reproductive organs (ex. penis and testicles). They also treat problems in the urinary tracts of men and women.
Social Workers help patients in many different ways. They help with finding safe living areas for elderly or children. They also have resources for patients fighting addiction or patients who need assistance once they leave the hospital.
A cardiologist is a doctor who specializes in caring for the heart. They use medicine and also do more in depth tests and procedures.
These are a group of doctors called surgeons. They help treat or fix diseases inside of the body by doing surgery or using medicines.
Drawn at 3 hour or 6 hour intervals, this blood test is a second test which checks for an increase in protein released from the heart, possibly from a heart attack or other heart condition.
These are doctors who specialize in eyes. They treat infections, diseases and injuries that occur to the eyes as well as perform eye surgery.
These are doctors who treat broken bones by doing surgery or by putting on casts or splints. They also replace joints such a knees or hips.
Complete Blood Count Basic Metabolic Panel or Electrolyte Panel B-type Natriuretic Peptide Internal Normalized Ratio Comprehensive Metabolic Panel Serum lipase Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate echocardiogram Cardiac Troponin Fibrin Degradation Fragment stool sample liver function test Human chorionic gonadotropin thryoid stimulating hormone serum uric acid blood typing Urine Screening arterial blood gas, venous blood gas electrocardiogram intravenous catheter intravenous therapy/hydration influenza test Strep Throat Test blood sugar level foley catheter, in/out cath Breathing Treatment Narcotic, non-narcotic, NSAIDS, central analgesics, topical anesthetics Antiemetics RBC & FFP Tetanus Computed Tomography abdominal ultrasound, fetal ultrasound, trans-vaginal ultrasound Magnetic Resonance Imaging Echocardiogram Treadmill Test O2 Obstetrics and Gynecology C-reactive protein Lactate Heart Monitor
